main
Class Monom

java.lang.Object
  main.Monom

public class Monom
extends java.lang.Object

The data Structure of a Monom

Author:
chrissy

A Monom is generally coded by x1x2...xn.
We can use negation by (~xi) and we can left out an entry by [xi]. To left out an entry is very important for the later Quine-Mc-Kluskey-Algorithm which deletes entries of Monoms if both boolean values in one signature is given. A signature is something like x1x2-x4 which results in melting the two monoms x1x2"0"x4 and x1x2"1"x4. This signature is coded by String as x1x2[x3]x4; leaving x3 deleted.

The static global variable Constraints.maxIndex controls the length of the monom. If maxIndex = 11 - the absolut maximum - the monoms have a length of 10 because their counters start at 1 not at zero as usual and maxLength is an strict upper-bound to the length of the monoms. This makes it easier to understand a monom in the following notation: x1x2...xn; here ie. x1x2...x10.
To get a more precisely view to this see the Constructor public Monom(boolean boolMonome[])

Field Detail

stringMonom

private java.lang.String stringMonom
used for internal conversions from String to Monom and the other way around

monomCopy

private Monom monomCopy
only used to copy the current monom

parseString

private java.lang.String parseString
This string is used to parse a monom like x1[x2](~x3) to 1-0.
ATTENTION: A complete String-Representation of 10 Varibales is x1x2x3...x9x0. Thus the index 0 represents the array-index 10. Look at getIndex to see the correct translation.
The parser overwrites the entries of intMonom and depends on Constraints.maxLength;

intMonome

public int[] intMonome
This is the main array which represents the states of the monom. We used an integer array because we want to represent also delted entries by QMC-Alg. which gets the value 2. Value 0 and 1 has the standard meaning of "true" and "false".
Other entries greater than 2 represent some errors. But they should not appear by using the standard methods.

stringRepresentation

protected int stringRepresentation
This variable controlls which String output you get by the toString() method. 0 - standard 0 to 2 expression 1 - is the monom expression 010-1001-0 2 - is the latex expression to export

eraseVariable

public void eraseVariable()
aim: delete an Variable in a Monom not implemneted yet

getSignature

public java.lang.String getSignature()
Returns:
the Signature of the current monom.
The signature of a monom is for example x1-(~x3)x4, if the second entry is already melted. To meld monoms see the details of the QMC-Alg. The signature is describe precisely at the beginning of the Monom-Class.

getVariableSignature

public java.lang.String getVariableSignature()
Returns:
the Variable-Signature of the monom. The Variable-Signature of a monom is similiar to the Signature of a monom except that the entries 'X' are now replaced by the name of the variable. For example 0-10 haf the variable-signature x1-x3x4. Remark: x0 is used to notate x10.

equals

public boolean equals(Monom m)
Remember that equals always has to be an equivalence relation!

Parameters:
m - monom to compare with the actual monom
Returns:
true iff the actual monom is equal to m

countBinaries

public int countBinaries()
We introduce some useful count methods here.
ATTENTION: the count methods don t count the melted entries marked by "-"

Returns:
counts the binary bits (i.e 0 or 1) inside m

countEntries

public int countEntries()
Returns:
count the entries of the monom m seems to be the same value as @see countBinaries

the number of ones in the monom

getLength

public int getLength()

the length of the current monom
Remeber that the length of the monom is the number of the entries plus 1 because we start counting by 1.

getDecimalValue

getIndex

private static int getIndex(char c)
Parameters:
c - Translates the char-Index to the array-index.
In the input-String x1x2...x9x0, x0 stands for x10; thus 0 is converted to the array index 10.

translateString

protected int[] translateString(java.lang.String sMonom)
Internal method to convert a given String in the notation x1[x2](~x3) as 1-0 into the correct monom.
Here only the parsing is depending on Constraints.maxLength.

Parameters:
sMonom - the String that represents the monom
Returns:
the int-Array which represets the monom.
This is left as an return value to be able to get also an intArray from (perhabs)outside (later).
